Altitude Sickness - A disease that occurs to mountain climbers, hikers, skiers, or travelers at high altitude, usually when you go above 8,000 feet, you are at increased risk of altitude sickness. Due to altitude sickness- Altitude sickness is caused by low pressure and high oxygen levels at high altitudes. The faster you climb, the faster you will get altitude sickness. The best way to prevent altitude sickness is to climb slowly. It is a good idea to spend a few days climbing up to 9850 feet (3000). Climbing very slowly above this point so that the height at which you sleep does not rise more than 990 feet to 1640 feet (300 meters to 500 meters) per night. You are at high risk for acute mountain sickness if: You live at or near the sea level and go to great heights.You have had the disease before.Fast climbingalcohol or other substances usedYou have medical problems associated with the heart, nervous system or lungs.Symptoms of Altitude Sickness- Your symptoms will depend on the speed of your climb and how high you are. Symptoms range from mild to fatal. They can affect the nervous system, lungs, muscles, and heart. In most cases, the symptoms are mild. Symptoms of mild to moderate altitude sickness may include Difficulty sleepingdizzinessFatiguehead acheloss of appetiteVomiting or nauseaPounding heartShortness of breath with tiredness Symptoms with more severe altitude sickness include: Skin blue color (cyanosis)Chest tightness or congestionConfusioncoughcoughing up bloodLoss or loss of consciousness through social interactionGray or yellowInability to walk in a straight line, or walk at allShortness of breath at restTests that may occur include: Blood testBrain CT scanChest X-RayElectrocardiogram (ECG) (ECG)Potential Complications may include: Coma (unresponsiveness)Pulmonary edemaInflammation of the brain (cerebral edema)The deathHow to prevent altitude sickness? Slowly climbed the mountain. Gradual ascent is the most important factor to prevent acute mountain sickness.For every 2000 feet (600 meters) climbing above 8000 feet (2400 meters), stop for a day or two of rest.Sleep at low altitude when possible.Make sure you have the ability to land fast when needed.Learn to recognize the early signs of mountain sickness.If you are traveling above 9840 ft (3000 m), you should carry enough oxygen for several days.While climbing: Do not drink alcoholDrink plenty of water or fluidsTake regular meals that are high in carbohydratesYou should avoid high altitude when you have heart or lung disease.

“Remember that time spent on a rock climb isn't subtracted from your life span.” - Will Niccolls Acute mountain sickness, commonly known as altitude sickness, might develop during the adjustment to the changes in air quality at higher elevations. It mostly happens at about 8,000 feet, or 2,438 meters, above sea level. Altitude sickness may occur once you jaunt to a high altitude too quickly. Breathing becomes troublesome because you are not able to soak up the maximum amount of oxygen. Age, sex or physical fitness have no bearing on your probability of obtaining altitude sickness. Just because you haven't had it before does not imply you will not develop it on another trip. Symptoms of altitude sickness typically develop between 6-24 hours once reaching altitudes greater than 3,000m (9,842 feet) above sea level.  Symptoms are close to those of a bad hangover. They include: HeadacheNauseaVomitingDizzinessTirednessLoss of appetiteShortness of breathLightheadednessRapid pulse or heartbeatThe symptoms are usually worse at night
